This all started out when I was a young kerbal, an intelligent one too. My father, Bill Kerman, was a space pioneer; you know the early kerbals that went to space. My father taught me about the Kerbal Universe and Physics and the science of spaceflight. I was instantly fascinated with space and flight. When I was young, kerbals in school would call me a nerd and a geek, but I ignored it and just concentrated on doing well in school so I could be a kerbalnaut just like my dad. After I graduated, I went to Kerbal Space Institute to get a degree in aeronautical engineering. With my success, I got my degree and got a job at KASA as an engineer. Then one day, when I was working on a blueprint for a Duna rover, my boss came to me and asked me if I wanted to study a new jet propulsion engine in space. I told him yes immediately and he told me that I was going to have training for two days and the launch was in four days. That night, I told my father and he was extremely proud of me.
